DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Jack Weakens, But Still Threatens Guam
Eds: Subs 2nd graf with 2 grafs to update position, weakening.
DOC.TEXT: A weakening Typhoon Jack began to drift toward this U.S. territory in the western Pacific today and was forecast to at least brush the island on Friday, according to civil defense officials. At 1 a.m. Thursday, (10 a.m. today EST), the storm was 190 miles east of Guam, moving west-southwest at about 3 mph. Its sustained wind speed was 85 mph with gusts to 100 mph. On Tuesday, its sustained winds were 135. Lt. Richard Bouchard of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center here said at the rate the storm was weakening it could lose typhoon status _ sustained wind speed of at least 74 mph _ before it passes south of Guam. ``Forecasters can't determine how close it will come, but it's expected to pass Guam during the day Friday,'' said George Toves, a Guam Civil Defense officer. ``We'll get some portion of it.'' The storm had been stalled about 200 miles east of Guam since early Tuesday.
